subjects.name: JavaScript Complete Course
subjects.description: Master JavaScript from basics to advanced with detailed examples and explanations

topics.title: Introduction to JavaScript
topics.description: Understanding JavaScript fundamentals and its role in modern web development

contents.title: What is JavaScript?
contents.content:
JavaScript is a high-level, interpreted programming language that is one of the core technologies of the World Wide Web, alongside HTML and CSS.

History:
â€¢ Created by Brendan Eich in 1995 at Netscape
â€¢ Originally called LiveScript, renamed to JavaScript for marketing
â€¢ Standardized as ECMAScript (ES)
â€¢ Latest version: ES2023 (ES14)

Key Characteristics:
â€¢ Interpreted language (no compilation needed)
â€¢ Dynamically typed (types determined at runtime)
â€¢ Prototype-based object-oriented
â€¢ First-class functions
â€¢ Event-driven and asynchronous
â€¢ Single-threaded with event loop

Where JavaScript Runs:
â€¢ Web Browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
â€¢ Servers (Node.js, Deno, Bun)
â€¢ Mobile Apps (React Native, Ionic)
â€¢ Desktop Apps (Electron)
â€¢ IoT Devices (Johnny-Five)

Why Learn JavaScript?
â€¢ Most popular programming language (GitHub, Stack Overflow)
â€¢ Essential for web development
â€¢ Full-stack development possible (MERN, MEAN)
â€¢ Huge job market demand
â€¢ Active community and ecosystem
â€¢ Easy to learn for beginners

contents.title: JavaScript vs Other Languages
contents.content:
JavaScript vs Java:
â€¢ Completely different languages
â€¢ JavaScript: interpreted, dynamically typed
â€¢ Java: compiled, statically typed
â€¢ JavaScript: prototype-based
â€¢ Java: class-based

JavaScript vs Python:
â€¢ Both are high-level, interpreted
â€¢ JavaScript: primarily for web
â€¢ Python: general-purpose
â€¢ JavaScript: event-driven
â€¢ Python: procedural/OOP

JavaScript vs TypeScript:
â€¢ TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript
â€¢ TypeScript adds static typing
â€¢ TypeScript compiles to JavaScript
â€¢ TypeScript better for large projects

contents.title: Your First JavaScript Program

examples.title: Console Output Methods
examples.explanation: console.log() is the most common way to output data in JavaScript. You can log strings, numbers, variables, and multiple values at once.

examples.title: Running JavaScript
examples.explanation: JavaScript can run in browser console, inside HTML <script> tags, or in external .js files linked to HTML.

contents.title: JavaScript Syntax Rules
contents.content:
Basic Syntax Rules:

1. Case Sensitive:
   â€¢ myVariable and MyVariable are different
   â€¢ console.log() not Console.Log()

2. Semicolons:
   â€¢ Optional but recommended
   â€¢ let x = 5; (with semicolon)
   â€¢ let x = 5  (without semicolon)

3. Whitespace:
   â€¢ Ignored by JavaScript
   â€¢ Use for readability

4. Naming Conventions:
   â€¢ camelCase for variables: myVariableName
   â€¢ PascalCase for classes: MyClassName
   â€¢ UPPERCASE for constants: MAX_VALUE

5. Reserved Keywords:
   â€¢ Cannot use: if, else, for, while, function, etc.
   â€¢ Full list: break, case, catch, class, const, continue, debugger, default, delete, do, else, export, extends, finally, for, function, if, import, in, instanceof, let, new, return, super, switch, this, throw, try, typeof, var, void, while, with, yield

6. Identifiers:
   â€¢ Must start with letter, $, or _
   â€¢ Can contain letters, digits, $, _
   â€¢ Cannot start with digit
